commentBody: Shenanigans!
What fun to find a Wednesday rebus! Enjoyed it a lot.

I don't mind rebuses at all, and this one was fine for a Wednesday. This took 65% of my average time, so my only minor gripe would be to change some of the cluing to make it slightly more challenging.

But overall, not a bad Wednesday puzzle.
The only things I dislike more than rebuses are non-Thursday rebuses üòèü§®
12 minutes, but it felt like a long 12 minutes.

This puzzle was a welcome RAY of sunshine, featuring the gentlest of rebuses.  I would even go so far as to say it is the perfect puzzle to introduce the uninitiated to the rebus concept.  The rebus was easy to spot and repeated itself, so, once gotten, it became even easier to spot the other rebus squares.  For myself, I‚Äôd prefer a more challenging rebus, but since this is only Wednesday, it‚Äôs probably best that the constructor tried to minimize potential blowback.

On a more serious note, I‚Äôd like to thank again all those who responded to my post on the Tuesday thread with kind thoughts, consoling words, especially those who shared their own stories.
A rebus, but only added a few minutes to my average Wed. time. At least it was consistent and logical.  Overall, a fine puzzle.
Thanks for a fun Wednesday puzzle. The repeated rebus added just enough challenge to keep me focused lest I be led astray‚Ä¶by the news or other folks in the house yelling about dinner or something.
Oh, great, now my calendar's broken üòÄ Nice crossword!

I think this is my first time figuring out a rebus without any hints. The trivia wasn‚Äôt too bad in this one, though I did need to look up where the WB archives are. All in all a very enjoyable puzzle and a great way to help pass some time during this power outage.

Nobody expects the Spanish Inqui....oops, I mean a Wednesday rebus. 
That was fun. I particularly liked the double RAY words, most especially  cRAY cRAY.

Hip Hip Hoo(RAY) for this gentle intro to rebuses! I finished quickly, then dawdled over reading about the Kray twins, gangsters in the 1950s-60s in London. For no good reason, I really wanted Ronald and Reginald to make an appearance in this grid. But cray cray is pretty close. And the rebus haters will remain silent, we p(RAY). 

Speaking of quick finishes, I recently watched WORDPLAY for the first time. I think it's from 2005, and centers around Will Shortz, some of the top competitive solvers and a few constructors. Probably most of you have seen it, and I wouldn't be surprised if a few of you participated in the tournaments. Top tier players can complete a Monday puzzle in well under 3 minutes and the Sat-Sun puzzles in 6-8 minutes. Sheesh!

The tournaments, you could tell, were lots of fun, lot of love and warmth and good humor, close friendships, nerd utopia. Maybe they still are. The emphasis is on speed for the competitive solvers, although Shortz and the constructors emphasize the beauty of xwords, their playfulness and restorative effects, and some of the celebrity solvers -- Bill Clinton, Mike Mussina, Indigo Girls, John Stewart -- also extol the play, art, charm, poetry, healthfulness, and bonhommie of doing xwords. Is there a way of balancing the two? Keeping a fine clip but appreciating the minutiae and finery? I haven't found it, and am a habitual last guest to leave, so I think these tourneys are not for me. But I loved the spirit they all displayed.

How many times did I look at my calendar to see what day it was?

Putting two rebuses in a single word is an evil genius move‚Ä¶ maybe even a little CRAY-CRAY! But I love the sneaky little R-squares, so I‚Äôm not complaining. Fun Wednesday!

I enjoyed this puzzle very much.  I was just beginning to suspect a rebus, when I opened up the Wordplay article, and read the first sentence.  Fortunately I found all the 'RAYs of sunshine' without much trouble.  Thank you!
A very fun Wednesday with a nice twist.

I kind of roll my eyes at all the folks who brag about how quick they get the rebus  puzzles. Ok so we get it, you‚Äôre soooo smart.  Joking not joking. I‚Äôm disappointed. I came to see everyone losing their üí© over a rebus in a Wednesday puzzle only to realize I‚Äôm early.
I thought it was a fun puzzle and I enjoyed catching some rays, something we‚Äôre sorely lacking in our weather.

Off topic, so here‚Äôs a mildly interesting one. I already mentioned that I completed yesterday‚Äôs (Tuesday‚Äôs) puzzle early in the AM ET, and when I went to read Sam‚Äôs column it had a date and time stamp of 6 AM Nov. 19 (traditionally there is only a date stamp). The column was about the Wednesday puzzle with a big spoiler in the first line. (KLW from NC also noticed this and made a post yesterday). The column was replaced with an editor‚Äôs apologia by about 11 AM ET yesterday. To make sure I wasn‚Äôt just dreaming, I had left an early morning post in the comment section. Today I see that this has been deleted, but it still exists somewhere in cyberspace. Maybe this is encouragement that our emu deleted posts may yet still be accessible out there somewhere‚Ä¶.See https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/43aqat?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share

I totally forgot about entering the rebus, and it solved with just R‚Äôs where RAY‚Äôs shoulda been entered.  I somehow thought the revealer was gonna be SHRINKflation or something‚Ä¶ thought just omitting the AY seemed okay or just‚Ä¶ OK.  It was!

Thank you, Robert Gard, it was a pleasure to spend an evening with you.
Nothing really to say except that I‚Äôm tired of the NYT comments system repeatedly moving me back to Texas. As of last Thursday, I don‚Äôt even have a valid Texas driver‚Äôs license!

After a long and physically tiring day, with little sleep the night before, I do not recommend starting the puzzle on a tablet, snuggled under a blanket on a couch. 

I woke up to find I'd entered a half dozen or so answers before conking out for 39 minutes.

I guess it is the puzzle time clock running that keeps the app alive and defeats the Android inactivity timer? Is this also an IOS issue?  Whatever it is, it would be nicer for your average if the app respected the inactivity setting.  I think I may have once had a 13  hour solve time due to this.

As many years as I‚Äôve been doing crosswords, I always feel an inner thrill when I figure out there‚Äôs a rebus going on, and an echo thrill when I figure out what it is.  I‚Äôve yet to respond with a flat, ‚ÄúOh, hmm, it‚Äôs a rebus.‚Äù  

Rebus themes often include punny revealers that justify them.  I love the challenge of leaving the revealer blank in a rebus puzzle and trying to crack what it is.  Today I was at wits end; nothing was coming to me that would justify stuffing RAY in the rebus squares.  

Oh, I love when that happens because my brain revels in the workout of popping out with wild stabs.  Eventually, though, I caved, resorted to crosses, uncovered the answer, nodded with respect, and sent a ‚ÄúWell played!‚Äù thought-a-gram to the constructor Robert.

Robert, you‚Äôve had three NYT puzzles ‚Äì Saturday, Tuesday, and Wednesday ‚Äì and only one constructor ‚Äì Andrew Reis ‚Äì has hit the cycle (a Times puzzle for every day of the week) in seven days.  Go for it!  And thank you for a most splendid outing today!

So today we had NSFW as an entry; and there has been recently been more than the usual complaints about the moderation filters used in these posts: frustration with the filters have nearly driven @Andzrej away, and I remember a time when Mr. Connell refused to post because of it. A couple days ago, a post of mine was held up for eight hours, as I had used, innocently, a word that moderation algorithm found offensive; and for that reason, in a post earlier today, I used then word "unclothed" when another word might be more natural.

I only bring this up because these censorship algorithm, in other contexts, can have some serious ramifications. An old friend of mine, a High School biology teacher, would complain that her students were limited in online research (while at school) because some sites were blocked: while researching astronomy, say, sites which discuss stars which "could be seen with the --eye," or--and of even more potential consequence--when researching women's health issues, discuss "--cancer."

"I bet in some of those Marvel Universe flicks that I've never seen and never will they have some sort of RAYgun that SHRINKs people instead of vaporizing them."  Why would you want to SHRINK them? i thought there was no way the NYTXW would have CRAY as an actual answer... only to find out it had it TWICE lol great wednesday puzzle - solvable and the right amount of challenge for this day of the week. great puzzle, you guys!

In any case, the could be a good candidate for a "gateway rebus" for those who think they are too hard or have some other objection to them. Easily doable, fairly clued, and with a clear revealer. 

Thanks for a Wednesday rebus!

No qualms, quibbles or questions from this solver. Whence uncovered, the squeeze play (rebus) serves as a pressure release valve. What the hey, every so often, the day of the week has been known to be as elusive as the solve. üòÅ
Being some what new to these crosswords was totally thrown by the little rays in the puzzle. Is this normal??

I rolled my eyes when I realized this was a rebus puzzle, but it was actually quite enjoyable! Six rebus squares felt like overkill at first, but I think the overuse is part of what made it easier to solve.

Rebus crosswords are horrible and should not be a thing because they fundamentally trash everything great about this kind of puzzle. The beauty in a crossword is that the rules are firmly established and it leaves no room for subjectivity. You know where the words go, the challenge is figuring out the words. And this can be a great challenge in and of itself.

Rebus crosswords introduce a random curveball that is understood only by the creator and leaves no indication for the player as to what the rules actually are. It's frustrating, unsatisfying and spoils what is otherwise a perfect game. If you want to create stuff like this, put it somewhere else. Leave my daily crosswards alone.

Loved this one.  I'm guessing I'm not the only one who  had 47A be the last to fall.  Despite the fact that I had been duly warned in 17-across that a single answer might have  two "rebi" in it (I'm going with OnceaMarine's plural), I  answered 47A with one rebus, giving "crayzy", quite happy with this alternative spelling and the crosses produced, "bazterium" as the culture group clued in 39D (no doubt some port in the Eastern Roman Empire  I had forgotten all about) and "gyareas" clued in 44D as open to interpretation (highly ambiguous symptoms, especially when occurring in series).  It was only when the happy sound failed to bleat that I was forced to reconsider.  I wonder if "craycray" is making its first NYT  Crossword appearance, since Google ngrams dates the start of its meteoric rise to about 2010.

Never been a big crossword solver and relatively new to the NYT puzzle. My average for a Wednesday puzzle is about 44 minutes. Today, with the rebus, a straight-up 16 minutes. This was a fun one. Look forward to dropping all my averages.

Lots of fun for a gloomy Wednesday. (We have an atmospheric river arriving soon.) I was only a little surprised to see a rebus on a Wednesday, but I do know they are not confined to Thursdays. What I will never understand is the anger expressed by some folks about rebus puzzles. Way too much anger floating around these days as it is. 
Thank you, Mr.Gard, and please keep them coming.

Despairing about how I'll ever realise about rebuses. I solved everything but -

- I assumed RBAN was an abbreviation used in the US, and MOREEL
- I assumed that BRS referred to some basketball/football team nicknamed Hee-Haws
- Never heard of food fights so the solution could have been anything, and so it was
- And so on.

What is CRAYCRAY and why are people so exited about it?

I did learn that a cravat is called an ascot

I enjoy unannounced rebuses because when the puzzler finally gets it there's a real feeling of accfomplishment.

But I don't care for the use of ephemeral slang like "cray-cray." 

Surely in a language as rich as English one can create a challenging grid without using terms that will never make it into the OED.
First time I think I ever picked up that it was a rebus AND solved it without peeking at the column first.
I don't like rebus puzzles.  Give them their own page.

Back today after a couple of weeks away; the jet lag is brutal, as is returning to heavy frost and 2 degrees Celsius after basking in 41c. Brr. 
To cap it all you give me rebi. On a Wednesday?! What are you doing to me? 
However, as it was so straightforward and a relatively simple one I forgive you.

I now need to stay awake till at least 8:30pm, having failed to make it beyond 7:30 the last two nights. Think I need to hit the archives to keep me going.

I've always loved the puzzles containing rebuses which often frustrated my father. I don't remember when I realized that they are usually on Thursday, but it seems to me that when I started doing the NY Times puzzle regularly back in the mid 80s, this was not a rule. Am I wrong? Anyway, I am happy to see them any day of the week. I think they bring an added challenge to any puzzle and bit of fun.

Just a little context re the question: How rare are Wednesday rebus puzzles?

2016 -- Zero Wednesday rebuses
2017 -- One Wednesday rebus
2018 -- Two Wednesday rebuses
2019 -- Two Wednesday rebuses
2020  -- Four Wednesday rebuses
2021 -- Four Wednesday rebuses.
2022 -- Four Wednesday rebuses.
2023 -- One Wednesday rebus.
2024 (so far) -- Two Wednesday rebuses.

Looks to me like 2020-22 was the Wednesday rebus heyday; no other year since the Shortz era began (1993) had four Wednesday rebuses.  And by the way, the first Wednesday rebus to appear in the Shortz era was in 1995.

If you know people dislike these and tend to complain when you spring them on us, why do it? And why not just simply warn people when they do appear? Crosswords have such a bad reputation among most people under 50 these days in part because of the perception of snobbery from the people that make, publish, and complete them. Throwing a mechanic into the puzzle that breaks the rules without telling people does not "add to the fun" if you don't even know that these mechanics exist, so you never know to even try them. It's 2024. We've got decades of research on how to design good games thanks to the video game and board game booms. There's no reason for crosswords to still be stuck in the 70s and smugly setting up artificial barriers for newcomers. Rule 1 is to make sure players have access to the rules in one way or another. If you've never met a rebus before you have no way to figure them out short of either cheating your own understanding of the rules or looking up answers.

@Bethany 

This forum is for people of all levels and abilities.  When someone tells you a puzzle took them 65% of their average, they're not bragging.  They're saying they found that day's puzzle on the easy side.  You don't know if their average is five minutes or fifty-five.

Most people don't talk about actual times unless the thread somehow is specifically related to it.  But newcomers should not view this as bragging; is it bragging when you hear that Tiger Woods shot a 68 on a certain day?  When you can't even break 100 on a good day?  

Solving quickly is a sign of experience combined with awareness of the outside world.  Intelligence figures into it somewhat--see my reply to Alice a little earlier--but largely is not a major factor.  Experience is the factor that helps you realize you're looking at a rebus within the first corner of the puzzle.

Is the typist who can do 75 words per minute particularly smart?  Is the world's fastest runner necessarily the world's smartest person?

When you have solved for decades, you will probably solve in 12 minutes or even less.  But you're there for the satisfaction.  If you've got that, you've achieved your goal for the time you put in.
